text:
<@URAV154AV> <@U0359RCHAGY> <@UUH2ESL66> <@U017WRJTKF1> <@U033KHGTDHC> <@U036K0S6AQJ> thanks SO MUCH for taking the time to help me out.

It seems like the consensus everywhere seems to be short forms convert better but long forms “qualify” better. One thing we do at Chili Piper is use short forms but enrich with Clearbit. It seems to work well if you ask the right qualifying questions.

Have any of you tried a similar tactic?

text: Hi everyone! What is the best way to ask for a quote from an expert/thought leader apart from interviewing them? I generally reach them out and ask them to share their take on the topic that we can add as a quote in our content. However, I’m assuming there are better ways to go about it.

elements.text: Hi everyone! What is the best way to ask for a quote from an expert/thought leader apart from interviewing them? I generally reach them out and ask them to share their take on the topic that we can add as a quote in our content. However, I’m assuming there are better ways to go about it.

text: I use a question approach. I leave it open ended so they can go as deep as they want to. For example, I can ask something like "what would you prioritize when doing ABC as a newbie?"

elements.text: I use a question approach. I leave it open ended so they can go as deep as they want to. For example, I can ask something like "what would you prioritize when doing ABC as a newbie?"
Hey

text: I have previously sent 3-minute Loom videos or audio clips where I talk through a question that has been sent my way w/out the need to be on a formal interview :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I have previously sent 3-minute Loom videos or audio clips where I talk through a question that has been sent my way w/out the need to be on a formal interview

text:
I'm looking for ways we can increase the impact of our case studies, because they're probably one of the most important content assets for our business right now. Would love to hear some creative ways y'all have (or have seen) given case studies more legs/reused or referenced content in other assets/channels, whatever.

Also - one thought I had to do that is to create sharing guides for our sales and exec teams (social sharing tips, email copy, and a general idea of when this piece of content would be the right share to a prospect/client). if anyone has done that before and has insights/tips, would love to hear those also!

elements.text:

Also - one thought I had to do that is to create sharing guides for our sales and exec teams (social sharing tips, email copy, and a general idea of when this piece of content would be the right share to a prospect/client). if anyone has done that before and has insights/tips, would love to hear those also!

text: Does anyone have experience creating XR content for B2B SaaS? I know XR is really popular in B2C - curious to know if there are B2B use cases out there.

elements.text: Does anyone have experience creating XR content for B2B SaaS? I know XR is really popular in B2C - curious to know if there are B2B use cases out there.

text:
A sharing guide sounds fantastic! A few of my clients would definitely benefit from something like this. I think the challenge is how to create it, where it lives and how to make it easy-access so they actually use it.

Following for ideas :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
A sharing guide sounds fantastic! A few of my clients would definitely benefit from something like this. I think the challenge is how to create it, where it lives and how to make it easy-access so they actually use it.

Following for ideas

text:
Following for ideas too! One thing we’ve done with our bigger name case studies is using them as the CTA with relevant email lists we sponsor, vs sending readers to other pages on our site. Good results so far.

We’re also planning to make short, 1-2 min video summaries of our case studies, since we already have the recorded interviews. Can’t speak to any results there yet, though.

elements.text:
Following for ideas too! One thing we’ve done with our bigger name case studies is using them as the CTA with relevant email lists we sponsor, vs sending readers to other pages on our site. Good results so far.

We’re also planning to make short, 1-2 min video summaries of our case studies, since we already have the recorded interviews. Can’t speak to any results there yet, though.

text: <@U02AR2XSN1M> I worked on a somewhat similar project for a freelance client last year—IntouchGroup is an umbrella agency that has sub-agency brands tailored to media, marketing, analytics, etc. We structured their site to encompass its sub-brands, which each has its own site that follow a similar structure and design patterns but speak to their specific audiences and services. I’m not sure the copy on the dropdown nav is 100% effective but I do think they handled the challenge pretty well overall. <https://www.intouchg.com/>

elements.text: I worked on a somewhat similar project for a freelance client last year—IntouchGroup is an umbrella agency that has sub-agency brands tailored to media, marketing, analytics, etc. We structured their site to encompass its sub-brands, which each has its own site that follow a similar structure and design patterns but speak to their specific audiences and services. I’m not sure the copy on the dropdown nav is 100% effective but I do think they handled the challenge pretty well overall.

text: In a prior in-house role, I created a private Google microsite specifically for the sales team that organized content, including case studies, by persona and buyer stage. It included links and brief descriptions of the content, as well as a shortcut hashtag that the sales team could enter in their CRM (Hubspot) emails. The hashtag automatically expanded to a short sentence with an embedded link to the piece of content. It was a lot of work to set up initially but the sales team really loved it, and it wasn’t hard to maintain.

elements.text: In a prior in-house role, I created a private Google microsite specifically for the sales team that organized content, including case studies, by persona and buyer stage. It included links and brief descriptions of the content, as well as a shortcut hashtag that the sales team could enter in their CRM (Hubspot) emails. The hashtag automatically expanded to a short sentence with an embedded link to the piece of content. It was a lot of work to set up initially but the sales team really loved it, and it wasn’t hard to maintain.

text: As far as reusing/repurposing case studies, I really like how one of my clients, SheerID, repurposes their customer stories. They offer identity verification services for exclusive discounts, like military or teacher discounts. They have traditional customer stories that describes the challenge/solution/results of implementing their service, and then a magazine-style “lookbook” that showcases how their customers develop and promote their discounts to their communities. So the former is a bit more of a BOFU sales-conversion play, while the latter is a bit more of an inspirational mid-funnel play.  Both make use of the same stats and quotes, and use source material from the initial customer interview. You can see an example of a case study here <https://resources.sheerid.com/retail/asics-success-story> and a Lookbook entry from the same brand here: <https://ebooks.sheerid.com/rise-lookbook/asics/>

attachments.fallback: ASICS Delivers on its Brand Promise and Increases Conversions by 100%
attachments.text: ASICS has experienced great success with special offers to consumer communities.
attachments.title: ASICS Delivers on its Brand Promise and Increases Conversions by 100%
